awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Optimal Design of a Teleretinal Screening Program for At-Risk Patients
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will contribute to the advancement of the national health and welfare by studying effective use of teleretinal screening and design of an integrated screening system for diabetic retinopathy. Diabetic retinopathy is the most common diabetic eye disease in the US and the leading cause of blindness in American adults. While diabetes-related vision loss is mostly preventable with early detection and treatment, national screening rates are significantly lower than desired, with disproportionately limited access for minority patients with a low socioeconomic status. This award supports a fundamental understanding of screening system design that utilizes teleretinal imaging technology to reduce the disparities and increase population-level screening. This project is expected to have a particular impact on the health and welfare of minority and underrepresented patients by identifying cost-effective screening policies and optimal screening locations. This award will fund a doctoral student in inter-disciplinary research and create educational materials for both operations researchers and healthcare professionals in ophthalmology, telehealth, and public health.

This research will model an integrated screening system design in a bilevel optimization framework: (i) the leader's problem is modeled as a probabilistic maximal covering location problem to identify optimal locations of teleretinal screening facilities in a large county health system, and (ii) the followers' problems address screening decisions for individual patients and are modeled as partially observable Markov decision processes to maximize both health benefit and patient adherence. Because of the computational challenges of the bilevel framework, the research will develop appropriate approximations by analyzing solution structures and value functions of the lower-level problems that enable simple solution forms and developing geography-based, distributed heuristics that approximate the interaction between the location decisions and patient-level screening decisions. The research is expected to lead to advances in bilevel optimization where there are many lower-level problems involving stochastic and sequential decision making.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Teleretinal imaging (TRI) has recently received increasing attention as an accessible screening technique for diabetic retinopathy (DR). However, little is known how the existing DR screening programs can incorporate this emerging technology and promote participation of patients with low adherence and limited access to care. Furthermore, there is a lack of quantitative understanding of the trade-offs between TRI and the existing in-clinic screening (CS) exams for different patient subgroups, and how screening recommendations should be personalized based on the trade-offs.

This project aims to develop a comprehensive, quantitative modeling framework to optimize a TRI screening program from both societal and individual patient's perspectives. Specifically, this project has the following goals:

- Model a personalized decision support tool that determines when and where each patient should receive which type of screening exams so as to maximize health utility while minimizing costs.

- Optimize TRI sites in a large urban area to maximize population-level screening and reduce disparity in access to screening.

- Integrate the two above models to develop a holistic TRI screening design platform.

We have developed a personalized screening decision-making model using a partially observable Markov decision process (POMDP). This model incorporates each patient’s unique characteristics including both social, behavioral, and health-related factors from the electronic medical record (EMR) database, and makes a screening recommendation every 6 months or whenever a patient visits a clinic. The model has been thoroughly validated based on the existing large-scale clinical trials data and tested retrospectively using the EMR data from the Baylor College of Medicine and Harris Health System in Houston, Texas.

The POMDP model adapts screening recommendations to each patient’s social, behavioral, and health-related factors such as willingness to pay, screening compliance, blood sugar level and DR progression. Our results indicate that the model recommends more frequent TRI screenings for patients who are less compliant with CS recommendations or have more severe geographic or financial barriers. On the other hand, the model recommends fewer TRI screenings for older patients or those with higher A1C levels (i.e., indicating a higher risk of developing sight-threatening disease). Simulation results based on a hypothetical cohort representing the Harris Health System patient population show that a screening policy with the model-based, personalized TRI recommendations is cost-effective, outperforming the current clinical screening guideline and other standardized guidelines in terms of both cost-saving and health benefit.

Patient-level understanding of DR screening demands was then further extended to the societal perspective to optimize TRI screening locations. A mathematical optimization model such as a probabilistic maximal covering model was used to determine optimal locations of TRI sites in Harris County, Texas, a large urban area with highly heterogeneous and uncertain screening demands. Our research shows that poor compliance with eye clinic-based screening recommendations is associated with a patient’s distance to the clinic, and incorporating these factors in location decision-making can produce an updated geographic setting for the TRI program that further improves the cost-effectiveness of the existing program.

This project offers intellectual merit by proposing a novel framework that integrates system-level screening location identification and patient-level sequential decision-making, posing a computationally challenging optimization problem. This project also proposes a new preference learning technique that quantifies each patient’s screening preference based on past screening decision data, which in turn can be explicitly incorporated into the patient-level screening recommendations.

The broader impacts of this project can be felt in multiple dimensions. One of the biggest challenges in DR management today is low patient compliance, particularly among minority and medically underserved populations. This research proposes a personalized TRI screening policy to reach out to patients with limited access to care, improve fairness, and increase population-level screening. Such a personalized policy can guide the development of a clinical decision support tool that can be used not only by patients but also by primary care physicians and eye care professionals. The results of this project can also inform evidence-based policymaking regarding camera placement, screening costs, and incentives to encourage patients to use TRI. Finally, the outcomes of this project will have an impact on other applications of similar store-and-forward telehealth services such as tele-dermatology. Decisions on the type and timing of various telehealth screening and treatment techniques can be supported by the optimization models developed in this project.
